jtxt.emulator

Class GString

  • java.lang.Object
    • jtxt.emulator.GString
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<Glyph>

    public final class GString
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<Glyph>
    A string of glyphs, with various methods to aid in the conversion of an escaped String into individual character elements and persisted in an instance of this class. This is effectively a replacement for strings, where each character has color information embedded with it.
    See Also:
    Glyph

    • Field Detail

      • glyphs

        private final Glyph[] glyphs
        The glyphs that this string contains. As this class mimics String itself, it's meant to be immutable; the size and values stored in this array should never change once initialized.

    • Constructor Detail

      • GString

        public GString(Glyph[] glyphs)
        Constructs a new GString from the array of glyphs.
        Parameters:
        glyphs - The glyphs this string should contain.

    • Method Detail

      • length

        public int length()
        Returns the length of this string of glyphs. Note that if this object was created by the GString#of(String) method, the length of this object may not necessarily be the same length as the given string. See this method for more information about how glyphs are constructed from their respective string representation.
        Returns:
        The length of this string of glyphs.

      • get

        public Glyph get(int index)
        Gets the glyph in this string at the given index. This method is analagous to charAt.
        Parameters:
        index - The index within this string to use.
        Returns:
        The glyph in this string at the given index.

      • concat

        public GString concat(GString other)
        Appends the given string to this one. Glyphs belonging to each string retain their respective properties during this process. Color information may differ between the two.
        Parameters:
        other - The string to append to this one.
        Returns:
        A new GString containing the elements of this string followed by the elements of the other, as if they were simply appended to the end of the array. (As color information is extracted during the conversion from a string to glyphs, escapes in one will not affect the other.)

      • insert

        public GString insert(int index,
                      Glyph glyph)
        Inserts a new glyph into this string at the index.
        Parameters:
        index - The index at which to insert the given glyph into the string.
        glyph - The glyph to insert.
        Returns:
        A new string containing the glyph inserted at the index. The glyph at the index, as well as all glyphs after it will have been shifted to the right to account for the inserted glyph.

      • append

        public GString append(Glyph glyph)
        Appends the given glyph to the end of this string. This is equivalent to concatenating this string with a string containing the given glyph, assuming that the string to be appended has a length of one.
        Parameters:
        glyph - The glyph to append to the end of this string.
        Returns:
        A new string containing this string and the given glyph inserted at the end, with a length of one + the length of this string.

      • set

        public GString set(int index,
                   Glyph glyph)
        Sets the glyph in this string at the index to the given glyph, discarding the glyph that was at that position within the string previously.
        Parameters:
        index - The position within this string to change the glyph of.
        glyph - The glyph that will replace the glyph which occupied this position previously.
        Returns:
        A new string with the given glyph at the index.

      • substring

        public GString substring(int start,
                         int end)

      • getData

        public java.lang.String getData(int start,
                                int end)
        Converts this string into a series of ANSI escape sequences so that it can be printed at a console. Color information is preserved.
        Parameters:
        start - The first character within this GString that should be escaped into a String.
        end - The last character in this GString that should be escaped.
        Returns:
        A substring of this GString that has color information embedded within it in the form of ANSI escape sequences.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • getStringFromArray

        private java.lang.String getStringFromArray(int[] string)

      • blank

        public static GString blank(int length)
        Creates a new string with blank Glyphs. This string is guaranteed to not appear in the terminal when rendered.
        Parameters:
        length - The number of null characters that the string should contain.
        Returns:
        A new GString containing all null Glyphs and has the length specified.
        See Also:
        Glyph.BLANK

      • of

        public static GString of(java.lang.String text,
                         java.awt.Color background)
        Constructs a GString for the given string of text. The presence of escape sequences in the string (delimited by \e[...m) is taken into account when constructing these glyphs; therefore, do not necessarily expect that the length of the given text and the length of the string returned by this method will be the same.
        Parameters:
        text - The string of text to convert to glyphs.
        background - The color which will appear behind the text. Use Glyph.TRANSPARENT if you wish to retain the default color of the terminal. (This is essentially a highlight color.)
        Returns:
        A GString with escaped values extracted and applied to their respective glyphs.

      • wrap

        public GString[] wrap(int length)
        Wraps this string to the given length. This method (rather primitively) breaks the string on the spaces between individual words.

        Implementation Note: This algorithm is greedy and makes no attempt to balance the distribution of Glyphs between lines.

        Parameters:
        length - The maximum number of Glyphs that can appear on a line before being wrapped.
        Returns:
        An array of GStrings, where each line's length is guaranteed to be no greater than the given length, and spaces between words at the rightmost bound of a line are discarded.

      • iterator

        public java.util.Iterator<Glyph> iterator()
        Specified by:
        iterator in interface java.lang.Iterable<Glyph>
